{{short description|Giving rights, freedom, and strengthening women to stand on their own feet}} {{Feminism sidebar}} [[File:MichelleObamaLetGirlsLearnCambodiaMar2015.jpg|thumb|Former First Lady [[Michelle Obama]] greets students during a Room to Read event with First Lady [[Bun Rany]] of [[Cambodia]] in support of the Let Girls Learn initiative, at Hun Sunni Prasat Bakong High School in [[Siem Reap]], Cambodia, March 21, 2015.]] '''Women's empowerment''' (or '''female empowerment''') is the process of [[empowering]] women.<ref name="Kabeer2005">Kabeer, Naila. "Gender equality and women'empoverment: A critical analysis o the third millennium development goal 1." ''Gender & Development'' 13.1 (2005): 13-24.</ref><ref name=":62">{{Cite journal |last=Mosedale |first=Sarah |date=2005-03-01 |title=Assessing women's empowerment: towards a conceptual framework|journal=Journal of International Development |language=en |volume=17 |issue=2 |pages=243–257 |doi=10.1002/jid.1212 |issn=1099-1328}}</ref> It may be defined in several ways, including accepting women's viewpoints or making an effort to seek them, raising the status of women through education, awareness, literacy, and training.<ref name="Bayeh2016">{{cite journal|last1=Bayeh|first1=Endalcachew|date=January 2016|title=The role of empowering women and achieving gender equality to the sustainable development of Ethiopia|journal=Pacific Science Review B: Humanities and Social Sciences |volume=2 |issue=1 |pages=38 |doi=10.1016/j.psrb.2016.09.013 |doi-access=free}}</ref> Women's empowerment equips and allows women to make life-determining decisions through the different problems in society.<ref name="Bayeh2016"/> They may have the opportunity to redefine [[gender role]]s or other such roles, which in turn may allow them more freedom to pursue desired goals.<ref name="Kabeer2005" />
Women's empowerment has become a significant topic of discussion in [[Human development (humanity)|development]] and [[economics]]. [[Economic empowerment]] allows women to control and benefit from resources, [[asset]]s, and [[income]]. It also aids the ability to [[Risk management|manage risk]] and improve women's well-being.<ref name="Women's Economic Empowerment Conceptual Framework">Oxfam (Forthcoming), "Women's Economic Empowerment Conceptual Framework"</ref> It can result in approaches to support trivialized [[gender]]s in a particular political or social context.<ref>{{Cite journal|last1=Baden|first1=Sally|last2=Goet|first2=Anne Marie|date=July 1997|title=Who Needs [Sex] When You Can Have [Gender]? Conflicting Discourses on Gender at Beijing|journal=Feminist Review|volume=56|issue=1|pages=3–25|doi=10.1057/fr.1997.13|s2cid=143326556|issn=0141-7789}}</ref> While often interchangeably used, the more comprehensive concept of [[gender empowerment]] concerns people of any gender, stressing the [[Sex and gender distinction|distinction]] between biological and [[Gender role|gender as a role]]. Women empowerment helps in boosting the status of women through literacy, education, training and awareness creation.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Lopez|first=Alvarez|date=2013|title=From unheard screams to powerful voices: a case study of Women's political empowerment in the Philippines|journal=12th National Convention on Statistics (NCS) EDSA Shangri-la Hotel, Mandaluyong City October 1–2, 2013}}</ref> Furthermore, women's empowerment refers to women's ability to make strategic life choices which had been previously denied them.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Innovation for women's empowerment and gender equality|url=https://www.icrw.org/publications/innovation-for-womens-empowerment-and-gender-equality/|access-date=2021-05-20|website=ICRW {{!}} PASSION. PROOF. POWER.|language=en-US|archive-date=2021-05-20|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210520123848/https://www.icrw.org/publications/innovation-for-womens-empowerment-and-gender-equality/|url-status=live}}</ref>
Nations, businesses, communities and groups may benefit from the implementation of programs and policies that adopt the notion of female empowerment.<ref name="Deneulin, Séverine 2009">{{cite web|url=https://idl-bnc.idrc.ca/dspace/bitstream/10625/40248/1/IDL-40248.pdf|title=An Introduction to the Human Development and Capability Approach: Freedom and Agency|year=2009|editor2=Lila Shahani|publisher=Earthscan|location=Sterling, VA|editor1=Deneulin, Séverine|access-date=2016-09-01|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160616162955/http://idl-bnc.idrc.ca/dspace/bitstream/10625/40248/1/IDL-40248.pdf|archive-date=2016-06-16|url-status=live}}</ref> Empowerment of women enhances the quality and the quantity of human resources available for development.<ref>{{Cite journal|last1=Gupta|first1=Kamla|last2=Yesudian|first2=P. Princy|date=2006|title=Evidence of women's empowerment in India: a study of socio-spatial disparities|journal=GeoJournal|volume=65|issue=4|pages=365–380|doi=10.1007/s10708-006-7556-z|s2cid=128461359}}</ref> Empowerment is one of the main procedural concerns when addressing [[human rights and development]].
== Definitions and methods == There are several principles defining women's empowerment such as, for one to be empowered, they must come from a position of disempowerment. They must acquire empowerment themselves rather than have it given to them by an external party. Other studies have found that empowerment definitions entail people having the capability to make important decisions in their lives while also being able to act on them. Empowerment and disempowerment are relative to the other at a previous time; as such, empowerment is a process rather than a product.<ref name=":62">{{Cite journal |last=Mosedale |first=Sarah |date=2005-03-01 |title=Assessing women's empowerment: towards a conceptual framework|journal=Journal of International Development |language=en |volume=17 |issue=2 |pages=243–257 |doi=10.1002/jid.1212 |issn=1099-1328}}</ref>
Scholars have identified two forms of empowerment, economic empowerment and political empowerment.<ref name="Kab2011">Kabeer, Naila. "Contextualising the Economic Pathways of Women's Empowerment: Findings from a Multi-Country Research Programme." (2011).</ref><ref name="UNDP2017">{{cite book |last1=United Nations Development Programme |last2=Stephanie Chaban; Luis J. Consuegra; Hannah Elten; Karin Gardes; Olivia Greymond; Olga Martin Gonzalez; Mona Lena Krook; Liri Kopaci-Di Michele; Hien Thi Nguyen; Nika Saeedi; Safi Trabelsi; Catherine Woollard |title=Regional organizations, gender equality and the political empowerment of women |date=2017 |publisher=International IDEA |location=Stockholm |isbn=978-91-7671-140-8 |url=https://www.undp.org/publications/regional-organizations-gender-equality-and-political-empowerment-women#modal-publication-download |access-date=2018-04-08|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180413044318/http://www.undp.org/content/undp/en/home/librarypage/democratic-governance/inclusive-political-institutions/regional-organizations--gender-equality-and-the-political-empowe.html|archive-date=2018-04-13|url-status=live}}</ref> Rahman et al. said that empowering women "puts a strong emphasis on participation in political structures and formal decision-making and, in the economic sphere, on the ability to obtain an income that enables participation in economic decision-making."<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Rahman|first1=Aminur|date=2013|title=Women's Empowerment: Concept and Beyond|url=https://globaljournals.org/GJHSS_Volume13/2-Womens-Empowerment-Concept.pdf|journal=Global Journal of Human Social Science Sociology & Culture|volume=13|issue=6|pages=9|access-date=11 December 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170810094216/https://globaljournals.org/GJHSS_Volume13/2-Womens-Empowerment-Concept.pdf|archive-date=10 August 2017|url-status=live}}</ref>
=== Economic empowerment === Since the 1980s, the push for [[neoliberalism]] prioritizes competitiveness and self-reliance as a measurement for economic success.<ref name="Lamont2008">{{Cite journal|last=Lamont|first=Michèle|date=June 2018|title=Addressing Recognition Gaps: Destigmatization and the Reduction of Inequality|url=http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/10.1177/0003122418773775|journal=American Sociological Review|language=en|volume=83|issue=3|pages=419–444|doi=10.1177/0003122418773775|issn=0003-1224|access-date=2021-05-12|archive-date=2021-04-28|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210428234337/https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/10.1177/0003122418773775|url-status=live}}</ref> The individuals and their identifying communities that do not meet society's favored neoliberal standards are looked down upon and are prone to lower their own self esteem.<ref name="Lamont2008" /> Some groups who do not fit the preferable neoliberal image are the lower working class and the unemployed.<ref name="Lamont2008" />
Specifically, neoliberalism has negatively impacted women's self-worth through its welfare reform policies. Mary Corcoran et al. theorize that conservative welfare reformers believe in welfare dependency as the cause of poverty.<ref name="Corcoran">{{cite journal |last1=Corcoran |first1=Mary |title=How welfare reform is affecting women's work |journal=Annual Review of Sociology |date=2000 |volume=26 |pages=241–269 |doi=10.1146/annurev.soc.26.1.241 |issn=0360-0572 |oclc=46615910}}</ref> This leads welfare reformers to widen the criteria for an individual to qualify as a welfare recipient, limiting the number of people dependent on welfare.<ref name="Corcoran" /> These criteria include: work requirements and time limits, rapidly pushing women into the labor market.<ref name="Corcoran" /><ref name="Abramovitz2006">{{Cite journal|last=Abramovitz|first=Mimi|date=May 2006|title=Welfare Reform in the United States: gender, race and class matter|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1177/0261018306062589|journal=Critical Social Policy|volume=26|issue=2|pages=336–364|doi=10.1177/0261018306062589|issn=0261-0183}}</ref> The active push for women to enter the labor market reinforces the notion that single mothers and unpaid care laborers are unproductive to the American economy.<ref name="Abramovitz2006" /> In consequence, women are forced to settle for low-paying unstable jobs while having to manage their maternal and domestic responsibilities.<ref name="Corcoran" /> Scholars believe welfare reform's underlying purpose is to disempower women by suppressing women's agency and economic independence.<ref name="Power2004">{{Cite journal|last=Power|first=Marilyn|date=November 2004|title=Social Provisioning as a Starting Point for Feminist Economics|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1080/1354570042000267608|journal=Feminist Economics|volume=10|issue=3|pages=3–19|doi=10.1080/1354570042000267608|issn=1354-5701}}</ref><ref name="Gutier1994">{{Cite journal|last1=Gutierrez|first1=Lorraine M.|last2=Lewis|first2=Edith A.|date=1994-07-07|title=Community Organizing with Women of Color:: A Feminist Approach|url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1300/J125v01n02_03|journal=Journal of Community Practice|language=en|volume=1|issue=2|pages=23–44|doi=10.1300/J125v01n02_03|issn=1070-5422}}</ref><ref name="Abramovitz2006" /> By creating opportunities for women empowerment like job training, women can counteract the social implications of neoliberalism and specifically welfare reform.<ref name="Power2004" /><ref name="Abramovitz2006" /><ref name="Corcoran" />
In addition, policy makers are suggested to support job training to aid in entrance in the formal markets.<ref name="Kab2011" /> One recommendation is to provide more formal education opportunities for women that would allow for higher bargaining power in the home. They would have more access to higher wages outside the home; and as a result, make it easier for women to get a job in the market.<ref name=":82">{{Cite journal|last=Duflo|first=Esther|date=2012|title=Women Empowerment and Economic Development|jstor=23644911|journal=Journal of Economic Literature|volume=50|issue=4|pages=1051–1079|doi=10.1257/jel.50.4.1051|url=https://dspace.mit.edu/bitstream/1721.1/82663/2/Duflo_Women%20Empowerment.pd|hdl=1721.1/82663|s2cid=17267963|hdl-access=free}}</ref>
Women's empowerment and achieving gender equality helps society ensure the [[sustainable development]] of a country. Many world leaders and scholars have argued that sustainable development is impossible without gender equality and women's empowerment.<ref name="Corcoran" /> Sustainable development accepts environmental protection, social and economic development, including women's empowerment. In the context of women and development, empowerment must include more choices for women to make on their own.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Mehra|first1=Rekha|date=November 1997|title=Women, Empowerment, and Economic Development|journal=The Annals of the American Academy of Political and Social Science|volume=554|issue=1|pages=136–149|doi=10.1177/0002716297554001009|s2cid=154974352}}</ref>
Strengthening women's access to property inheritance and land rights is another method used to economically empower women. This would allow them better means of asset accumulation, capital, and [[bargaining power]] needed to address [[gender inequalities]]. Often, women in developing and underdeveloped countries are legally restricted from their land on the sole basis of gender.<ref name=":82" /> Having a right to their land gives women a sort of bargaining power that they would not normally have; they gain more opportunities for economic independence and formal financial institutions.
Race has an integral impact on women's empowerment in areas such as employment. Employment can help create empowerment for women. Many scholars suggest that when we discuss women's empowerment, discussing the different barriers that underprivileged women face, which makes it more difficult for them to obtain empowerment in society, is important when examining the impact of race in connection to employment. Significantly examining how opportunities are structured by gender, race, and class can transpire social change. Work opportunities and the work environment can create empowerment for women. Empowerment in the workplace can positively affect job satisfaction and performance, having equality in the workplace can greatly increase the sense of empowerment.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Carr |first1=Gloria |title=Empowerment: A Framework to Develop Advocacy in African American Grandmothers Providing Care for Their Grandchildren |journal=ISRN Nursing |date=February 2011 |volume=2011 |pages=531717 |pmc=3169837 |pmid=21994894 |doi=10.5402/2011/531717 }}</ref>
In the case women have the opportunity to settle for stable jobs, [[Women of color]] encounter a lack of equal accessibility and privileges in work settings. They are faced with more disadvantages in the work place. Patricia Parker argues that [[African American]] women's empowerment is their resistance to control, standing up for themselves and not conforming to societal norms and expectations. In connection to power, feminist perspectives look at empowerment as a form of resistance within systems of unequal power relations. Within the societal setting of race, gender, and class politics, African American women's empowerment in the work environment "can be seen as resistance to attempts to fix meanings of appropriate identity and behavior, where such meanings are interpreted as controlling, exploitative, and other- wise oppressive to African American women."<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Parker |first1=Patricia |title=Control, Resistance, and Empowerment in Raced, Gendered, and Classed Work Contexts: The Case of African American Women |journal=Annals of the International Communication Association |date=2003 |volume=27 |issue=1 |pages=257–291 |doi=10.1080/23808985.2003.11679028 |s2cid=154928053 }}</ref> When talking about women's empowerment, many scholars suggest examining the social injustices on women in everyday organizational life that are influenced by race, class, and gender.
Another methodology for women's economic empowerment also includes [[microcredit]].<ref name="autogenerated22">{{cite report|url=https://www.un.org/womenwatch/daw/public/WorldSurvey2009.pdf|title=Women's Control over Economic Resources and Access to Financial Resources, including Microfinance|publisher=United Nations|location=New York|section=World Survey on the Role of Women In Development|year=2009|access-date=2017-06-29|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170829064329/http://www.un.org/womenwatch/daw/public/WorldSurvey2009.pdf|archive-date=2017-08-29|url-status=live}}</ref> Microfinance institutions aim to empower women in their community by giving them access to loans that have low interest rates without the requirement of collateral.<ref name="Geleta2014">Geleta, Esayas Bekele. "Microfinance and the politics of empowerment: a critical cultural perspective." ''Journal of Asian and African Studies'' 49.4 (2014): 413-425.</ref> More specifically, they(microfinance institutions) aim to give microcredit to women who want to be entrepreneurs.<ref name="Geleta2014" /> The success and efficiency of microcredit and microloans is controversial and constantly debated.<ref>{{cite journal|author1=Parmar, A.|year=2003|title=Microcredit, Empowerment, and Agency: Re-evaluating the Discourse|journal=Canadian Journal of Development Studies|volume=24|issue=3|pages=461–76|doi=10.1080/02255189.2003.9668932|s2cid=154860254}}</ref> Some critiques claim that microcredit alone doesn't guarantee women have control over the way the loan is used. Microfinance institutions don't address cultural barriers that allow men to still control household finances; as a result, microcredit may simply be transferred to the husband. Microcredit doesn't relieve women of household obligations, and even if women have credit, they don't have the time to be as active in the market as men.<ref name="Geleta2014" /><ref name=":11">Ellis, Amanda. ''Gender and economic growth in Kenya: Unleashing the power of women''. World Bank Publications, 2007.</ref>
=== Political empowerment === [[File:Shinzō Abe and Ivanka Trump (4).jpg|thumb|upright| Businesswoman [[Ivanka Trump]] (right) and [[Japanese Prime Minister|Japanese PM]] [[Shinzo Abe]] attending the World Assembly for Women in [[Tokyo]] to speak on women's rights and empowerment, 2017]]
Political empowerment supports creating policies that would best support gender equality and agency for women in both the public and private spheres. Methods that have been suggested are to create affirmative action policies that have a quota for the number of women in policy making and parliament positions.<ref name=":82" /> As of 2017, the global average of women who hold lower and single house parliament positions is 23.6 percent.<ref name="UNDP2017" /> Further recommendations have been to increase women's rights to [[vote]], voice opinions, and the ability to run for office with a fair chance of being elected.<ref name="Deneulin, Séverine 2009" /> Because women are typically associated with child care and domestic responsibilities in the home, they have less time dedicated to entering the labour market and running their business. Policies that increase their [[bargaining power]] in the household would include policies that account for cases of divorce, policies for better welfare for women, and policies that give women control over resources (such as property rights).<ref name=":82" /> However, participation is not limited to the realm of politics. It can include participation in the [[household]], in schools, and the ability to make choices for oneself. Some theorists believe that bargaining power and agency in the household must be achieved before one can move onto broader political participation.<ref>{{cite book|title=Women and Human Development: The Capabilities to Approach|url=https://archive.org/details/womenhumandevelo00nuss|url-access=limited|author=Nussbaum, Martha C.|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=2000|isbn=9781139459358|location=Cambridge, UK|pages=[https://archive.org/details/womenhumandevelo00nuss/page/n24 1]–33|chapter=Introduction}}</ref>
==== Digital skills enhance political empowerment ==== {{Main|Gender digital divide}}
Digital skills can facilitate women’s engagement with local [[government]] and increase their decision-making power in their communities. The Women-gov project in [[Brazil]] and [[India]], for instance, has helped women improve their understanding of and [[communication]] with local government via [[Information and communications technology|ICTs]].<ref name="unesco19">{{Cite web|last1=UNESCO|url=https://unesdoc.unesco.org/ark:/48223/pf0000367416.pdf|title=I'd blush if I could: closing gender divides in digital skills through education|last2=EQUALS Skills Coalition|date=2019|access-date=2020-03-05|archive-date=2020-03-30|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200330231252/https://unesdoc.unesco.org/ark:/48223/pf0000367416.pdf|url-status=live}}</ref> In [[Brazil]], the project trained female community [[Leadership|leaders]] to access and utilize [[online]] data on government [[Health care|health services]] to better respond to [[public health]] concerns in their communities. In [[India]], the project worked with women’s collectives to establish women-run, internet-connected community information centres to facilitate applications for government assistance (including [[welfare]] and entitlements), which in turn improved linkages between the collectives, local authorities and public institutions.<ref name="Romeo2016">Romeo, N. 2016. "The chatbot will see you now". ''New Yorker'', 25 December 2016.</ref>
Women with digital skills are better able to make their voices heard on local issues and influence the outcome of decisions that affect themselves and their communities. Digital skills can also empower women to participate in political movements.<ref name="unesco19" /> For instance, the anonymity of [[Information and communications technology|ICTs]] may allow some women to avoid limitations on [[freedom of speech]] in repressive societies, while collective mobilization through online networks can enable women to campaign on gender-based issues.<ref name="Romeo2016" /> Studies show an [[Iraq]]i women’s group used a multimedia campaign, including an online component, to successfully lobby the Kurdish regional government to [[outlaw]] the practice of [[female genital mutilation]].<ref>Shulevitz, J. 2018. Alexa, should we trust you? The Atlantic, November 2018.</ref> Images taken on [[mobile phone]]s and distributed via [[social media]] have called attention to [[domestic violence]] in [[China]] and influenced media treatment of court cases on forced [[abortion]].<ref>Wong, Q. 2017. Designing a chatbot: male, female or gender neutral? Mercury News, 5 January 2017.</ref>
=== Cultural Empowerment === As a progressive society, standing for women's rights and empowerment, we must stop viewing culture only as a barrier and an obstacle to women's rights.<ref name="OHCHR">{{Cite web |date=2012-11-08 |title=Women's cultural rights: Empowering and transformative |url=https://www.ohchr.org/EN/NewsEvents/Pages/WomenCulturalRights.aspx |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210802212753/https://www.ohchr.org/EN/NewsEvents/Pages/WomenCulturalRights.aspx |archive-date=2021-08-02 |publisher=Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights}}</ref> Culture is an integral and huge part of diversity and a medium that seeks to ensure women's equal opportunities.<ref name="OECD">{{Cite web |last=Schalkwyk |first=Johanna |title=CULTURE, GENDER EQUALITY AND DEVELOPMENT CO‐OPERATION |url=https://www.oecd.org/dac/gender-development/44750710.pdf |url-status=live |access-date=2021-09-10 |website=OECD.org |publisher=Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development |publication-date=June 2000 |archive-date=2021-08-25 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210825205310/https://www.oecd.org/dac/gender-development/44750710.pdf }}</ref> It recognises their freedom to take pride in their values, whether they are orthodox or modern in nature. This is not to say that centuries of abuse clothed in the spirit of culture should be allowed to continue, let alone be celebrated. Undoubtedly, traditions cloaked in the idea of empowerment should be objected to in light of feminism. For example, some research indicates that women only have an equal chance to have their written work published in peer-reviewed journals if the sex of the author is absolutely unknown to the reviewers.<ref name="OECD" /> This is a result of historical habitual culture which has led to lack of representation of women in literary and therefore, strongly demonstrated why all cultural legacies cannot and should not be celebrated or encouraged.
There is a need for equal cultural rights for women to be acknowledged and implemented which would in turn help to reconstruct gender in ways that would rise above women's inferiority and subordination. Furthermore, this would significantly improve the conditions for the full and equal enjoyment of their human rights on the whole as argued by the UN expert in the field of cultural rights, Farida Shaheed.
Shaheed continues to add that the perspective and contributions of women must transcend from the margins of cultural life to the centre of the process that creates and shapes cultures around the globe today.<ref name="OHCHR" /> “Women must be recognized as, and supported to be, equal spokespersons vested with the authority to determine which of the community’s traditions are to be respected, protected and transmitted to future generations.”<ref name="OHCHR" />
== Feminist approaches to women empowerment == Feminism is defined by the movement’s goal of creating women’s empowerment.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Emejulu|first=A.|date=2011-07-01|title=Re-theorizing feminist community development: towards a radical democratic citizenship|url=https://academic.oup.com/cdj/article-lookup/doi/10.1093/cdj/bsr032|journal=Community Development Journal|language=en|volume=46|issue=3|pages=378–390|doi=10.1093/cdj/bsr032|issn=0010-3802}}</ref> Two methods feminists use to facilitate a sense of women empowerment are consciousness-raising and building relationships with the women participants and their external oppressors.<ref name="Gutier1994" /><ref name="Erbaugh">{{Cite journal|last=Erbaugh|first=Elizabeth|title=Women's Community Organizing and Identity Transformation|journal=Race, Gender & Class|volume=9|pages=8–32|via=JSTOR}}</ref>
=== Raising consciousness === To create women empowerment, feminists commonly use consciousness raising.<ref name="Gutier1994" /> When raising consciousness, women not only become knowledgeable about their personal struggles but how it is related to political and economical issues.<ref name="Bradshaw1994">{{cite journal |last1=Bradshaw |first1=Catherine P. |last2=Soifer |first2=Steven |last3=Gutierrez |first3=Lorraine |title=Toward a Hybrid Model for Effective Organizing in Communities of Color |url=https://doi.org/10.1300/J125v01n01_03 |journal=Journal of Community Practice |date=January 1994 |volume=1 |issue=1 |pages=25–42 |doi=10.1300/J125v01n01_03 |issn=1070-5422}}</ref><ref name="Gutier1994" /> Raising consciousness allows marginalized individuals to see where they are placed in the larger social structure and pinpoint the root of their oppression.<ref name="Bradshaw1994" /><ref name="Gutier1994" /> Awareness of their problems will initiate self-mobilization which precisely creates empowerment.<ref name="Gutier1994" />
However, scholars Shane Brady and Mary O'Connor have pointed out the term “raising-consciousness” may be misunderstood and offensive to participants.<ref name=":6">{{Cite journal|last1=Brady|first1=Shane R.|last2=O’Connor|first2=Mary Katherine|date=2014-04-03|title=Understanding How Community Organizing Leads to Social Change: The Beginning Development of Formal Practice Theory|url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/10705422.2014.901263|journal=Journal of Community Practice|language=en|volume=22|issue=1–2|pages=210–228|doi=10.1080/10705422.2014.901263|issn=1070-5422}}</ref> Using the term “raising-consciousness” inflicts the notion that the marginalized community is not aware of their oppression and how to deal with it.<ref name=":6" />
=== Building relationships === In addition, feminists, specifically feminist organizers, focus on building relationships as a medium for creating women empowerment.<ref name=":6" /><ref name=":8">{{Cite journal|last1=Fisher|first1=Robert|last2=Shragge|first2=Eric|date=2000-11-28|title=Challenging Community Organizing: Facing the 21st Century|url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1300/J125v08n03_01|journal=Journal of Community Practice|language=en|volume=8|issue=3|pages=1–19|doi=10.1300/J125v08n03_01|issn=1070-5422}}</ref><ref name="Erbaugh" /> Scholars claim that building relationships results in empowerment because the increasing presence of power gaps in society are due to the lack of relationships that are needed to bridge them.<ref name="Christens2010">{{Cite journal|last=Christens|first=Brian D.|date=2010-08-03|title=Public relationship building in grassroots community organizing: relational intervention for individual and systems change|url=http://doi.wiley.com/10.1002/jcop.20403|journal=Journal of Community Psychology|language=en|volume=38|issue=7|pages=886–900|doi=10.1002/jcop.20403}}</ref> When it comes to forming and maintaining relationships, there needs to be a balance of both collaboration and conflict between the two parties.<ref name="Bradshaw1994" /><ref name="Christens2010" /> Conflict commonly arises in situations where community members attempt to build relationships with external power figures like government representatives.<ref name="Christens2010" /><ref name=":8" /> Fostering a space for collaboration as well as deliberation of conflicting ideas is important because sorting out disagreements<ref name="Christens2010" /> allows for the formation of trust between the parties.<ref name=":6" /> In addition, conflict individually benefits the women participants because it fosters problem-solving skills<ref name="Christens2010" /> and opens them to a new pool of knowledge and perspectives on society.<ref name="Christens2010" /> Scholars observe that building relationships has a depoliticizing tendency as the activity does not directly challenge the oppressive structures affecting women.<ref name="Christens2010" /> A specific observation of this depoliticizing tendency is story telling. When building relationships, feminists encourage women participants to share their personal experiences involving gender oppression, rather than deliberate about strategies to approach the oppressive system.
==Measurements and assessment== Women empowerment can be measured through the [[Gender Empowerment Measure]] (GEM), which calculates women's participation in a given nation, both politically and economically. GEM is calculated by tracking "the share of seats in [[parliament]] held by women; of female legislators, senior officials and managers; and of female profession and technical workers; and the [[gender disparity]] in earned income, reflecting economic independence".<ref name="Deneulin, Séverine 2009" /> It ranks countries given this information.
Some critiques of GEM is that it is not concerned with factors regarding society, such as gender, religion, cultural context, legal context, and violations of women's rights.<ref name=":02">Charmes, Jacques, and Saskia Wieringa. "Measuring women's empowerment: an assessment of the gender-related development index and the gender empowerment measure." ''Journal of Human Development'' 4.3 (2003): 419-435.</ref> Gender empowerment measure attempts to make a consistent standardized approach to measure women's empowerment; in doing so, it has been critiqued that the GEM doesn't account for variation in historical factors, female autonomy, gender segregation, and women's right to vote.<ref name="Pilla1998">{{Cite journal|last1=Pillarisetti|first1=J.|last2=McGillivray|first2=Mark|date=1998-06-01|title=Human Development and Gender Empowerment: Methodological and Measurement Issues|journal=Development Policy Review|language=en|volume=16|issue=2|pages=197–203|doi=10.1111/1467-7679.00059|issn=1467-7679}}</ref>
Other measures that calculate women's participation and relative equality include the [[Gender Parity Index]] (GPI) or the [[Gender-related Development Index]] (GDI).<ref name="Deneulin, Séverine 2009" /> The GDI is a way in which the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) measures the inequality between genders within a country. Some critique of this measurement is that, because GDI calculations rely solely on the achievement distribution between males and females of a population, GDI does not measure gender inequality; instead it measures absolute levels on income, education, and health.<ref name=":02" />
A more qualitative form of assessing women's empowerment is to identify constraints to action. This allows for the identification of power relations between genders. Because this is a participatory process, it facilitates conversation on gender discrimination.<ref name=":62"/> Comparing constraints on women at a later time also allows for any changes or expansion to be better identified. The evaluation of the development of women's agency allows for an evaluation of actions taken. These assessments must also be based on the action taken by women, and not external groups. External groups can help facilitate women's empowerment, but cannot bestow it on them.<ref name=":62" />
== Barriers == Many of the barriers to women's empowerment and equity are the result of [[cultural norm]]s. While many women are aware issues posed by gender inequality, others have become accustomed to it.<ref>{{cite book|title=Women, Culture, and Development: A Study of Human Capabilities|author=Nussbaum, Martha C.|publisher=Clarendon Press|year=1995|isbn=9780198289647|editor1=Martha C. Nussbaum|location=Oxford|pages=1–15|chapter=Introduction|editor2=Jonathan Glover|name-list-style=amp}}</ref> Many men in power are hesitant to disrupt societal norms that are unfair to women.<ref name="autogenerated2">{{cite report|url=https://www.un.org/womenwatch/daw/public/WorldSurvey2009.pdf|title=Women's Control over Economic Resources and Access to Financial Resources, including Microfinance|publisher=United Nations|location=New York|section=World Survey on the Role of Women In Development|year=2009|access-date=2017-06-29|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170829064329/http://www.un.org/womenwatch/daw/public/WorldSurvey2009.pdf|archive-date=2017-08-29|url-status=live}}</ref>
Research shows that the increasing access to the Internet can also result in an increased exploitation of women.<ref name="Sutton, J. 2000" /> Releasing personal information on websites has put some women's personal safety at risk. In 2010, Working to Halt Online Abuse stated that 73% of women were victimized through such sites. Types of victimization include [[cyber stalking]], harassment, [[online pornography]], [[flaming (Internet)|flaming]],<ref>{{cite journal|author=Morahan-Martin, J.|year=2000|title=Women and the Internet: Promise and Perils|journal= Cyberpsychology & Behavior|volume=3|issue=5|pages=683–691|doi=10.1089/10949310050191683}}</ref> and especially [[sexual harassment in the workplace]]. It occurs most frequently in business, trade, banking and finance, sales and marketing, hospitality, civil service, and education, lecturing and teaching.<ref name="Statistics">{{cite web|url=http://www.aware.org.sg/training/wsh-site/14-statistics/|title=Statistics|date=22 April 2010|work=AWARE RSS|publisher=AWARE|access-date=19 May 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160513181143/http://www.aware.org.sg/training/wsh-site/14-statistics|archive-date=13 May 2016|url-status=live}}</ref> According to the International Labour Organisation (ILO), sexual harassment is a clear form of gender discrimination based on sex, a manifestation of unequal power relations between men and women. The UN Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women (CEDAW) is urging for increased measures of protection for women against sexual harassment and violence in the workplace. 54% (272) had experienced some form of workplace sexual harassment. 79% of the victims are women; 21% were men.<ref name="Statistics" />
Studies show that women face more barriers in the workplace than men. Gender-related barriers involve sexual harassment, unfair hiring practices, career progression, and unequal pay where women are paid less than men are for performing the same job.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Stein, A.I.|year=2009|title=Women Lawyers Blog for Workplace Equality: Blogging as a Feminist Legal Method|url=http://digitalcommons.law.yale.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1287&context=yjlf|journal=Yale Journal of Law and Feminism|volume=20|issue=2|pages=357–408|access-date=2016-06-22|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160820031953/http://digitalcommons.law.yale.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1287&context=yjlf|archive-date=2016-08-20|url-status=live}}</ref> When taking the median earnings of men and women who worked full-time, year-round, government data from 2014 showed that women made $0.79 for every dollar a man earned. The average earnings for working mothers came out to even less—$0.71 for every dollar a father made, according to 2014 study conducted by the National Partnership for Women and Children. While much of the public discussion of the [[Gender pay gap|wage gap]] has focused around women getting equal pay for the same work as their male peers, many women struggle with what is called the "pregnancy penalty". This occurrence is difficult to measure, but the possibility of having a baby can be enough for employers to disrupt women's pay.<ref name="NBC">{{cite web|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/business/careers/motherhood-penalty-can-affect-women-who-never-even-have-child-n548511|title='Motherhood Penalty' Can Affect Women Who Never Even Have a Child|author=Safia Samee Ali|date=April 11, 2016|work=NBC News|access-date=June 22, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160620121244/https://www.nbcnews.com/business/careers/motherhood-penalty-can-affect-women-who-never-even-have-child-n548511|archive-date=June 20, 2016|url-status=live}}</ref> Women are put in a position where they need to make the decision of whether to maintain in the workforce or have children, which has led to the debate over [[maternity leave in the United States]] and many other countries in the world.
In March 2016, tech career website Dice released a study of more than 16,000 tech professionals that found that when equivalent education, experience and position are compared, there is no pay gap and there has not been one for the last six years.<ref name="NBC" />
== Role of education == People engage in public debate and make demands on government for health care, social security and other entitlements.<ref name="UNDP2013">UNDP. 2013. Human Development Report. The Rise of the South. Human Progress in a Diverse World; New York, UNDP.</ref> In particular, education empowers women to make choices that improve their children's health, their well-being, and chances of acquiring survival skills.<ref>UNESCO. 2014, 2020. EFA Global Monitoring Report 2013/2014: Teaching and Learning, Paris, UNESCO.</ref><ref name="Lamont2008" /> Education informs others of preventing and containing a disease. Such education empowers women to make choices that can improve their welfare, including marrying beyond childhood and having fewer children. Education can increase women's awareness of their rights, boost their self-esteem, and provide them the opportunity to assert their rights.<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0023/002343/234325E.pdf|title=Mobile phones and literacy: Empowerment in Women's Hands; A Cross-Case Analysis of Nine Experiences|last=UNESCO|publisher=UNESCO|year=2015|isbn=978-92-3-100123-9|location=33|access-date=2017-05-10|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170517175749/http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0023/002343/234325E.pdf|archive-date=2017-05-17|url-status=live}}</ref>
Education is not universally available and gender inequalities persist. A major concern in many countries is not only the limited numbers of girls going to school, but also the number of educational pathways for those that step into the classroom. There are efforts to address the lower participation and learning achievement of [[Female education in STEM|girls in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) education]].<ref>{{Cite book|title=Cracking the code: girls' and women's education in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM)|publisher=UNESCO|year=2017|isbn=9789231002335|location=Paris|pages=11}}</ref>
In some parts of the world, girls and women are attacked for attending school,<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.proliteracy.org/Blogs/Article/413/One-Girls-Courage-Leads-Women-to-Equal-Education-Opportunities |title=Archived copy |access-date=2021-04-05 |archive-date=2021-04-10 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210410143806/https://www.proliteracy.org/Blogs/Article/413/One-Girls-Courage-Leads-Women-to-Equal-Education-Opportunities |url-status=live }}</ref> and societal efforts to stop this may be lacking.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://womenatthecenter.org/images/education-images/malala-yousafzai-wins-nobel-peace-prize-education-and-girls-empowerment/ |title=Archived copy |access-date=2021-04-05 |archive-date=2021-08-31 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210831063221/http://womenatthecenter.org/images/education-images/malala-yousafzai-wins-nobel-peace-prize-education-and-girls-empowerment/ |url-status=live }}</ref>
== Internet use== The Internet is often a source of empowerment for women through its creation, dispersion, and utilization of [[hashtag]]s on [[social media]]. Growing Internet access in the late 20th century provided women with various tools to empower themselves. Women began to use social networking sites such as [[Facebook]] and [[Twitter]] for [[online activism]].<ref name="Sutton, J. 2000">{{cite journal|author1=Sutton, J.|author2=Pollock, S.|name-list-style=amp|year=2000|title=Online Activism for Women's Rights|journal= Cyberpsychology & Behavior|volume=3|issue=5|pages=699–706|doi=10.1089/10949310050191700}}</ref> Through online activism, they are able to empower themselves by organizing campaigns and voicing their opinions for equality rights.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Churchyard, N.|year=2009|title=The Question of Empowerment: Women's Perspective on Their Internet Use|journal=[[Gender, Technology and Development]]|volume=13|issue=3|pages=341–363|doi=10.1177/097185241001300302|s2cid=145005984}}</ref>
[[Blogging]] emerged as one tool for educational female empowerment. According to a study done by the University of California, Los Angeles, medical patients who read and write about their disease are often in a much happier mood and more knowledgeable than those who do not.<ref name="breastcancer.about.com">{{cite journal|author=Stephan, P.|date=August 13, 2013|title=Breast cancer patients blog their blues away|url=http://breastcancer.about.com/b/2013/08/13/blog-the-blues-away.htm|website=Breastcancer.about.com|access-date=September 17, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130816030742/http://breastcancer.about.com/b/2013/08/13/blog-the-blues-away.htm|archive-date=August 16, 2013|url-status=live}}</ref> By reading others' experiences, patients can better educate themselves and apply strategies that their fellow bloggers suggest.<ref name="breastcancer.about.com"/>
With the easy accessibility and affordability of [[e-learning]] (electronic learning), women can study from the comfort of their homes.<ref>{{cite journal|author1=Radovic-Markovic, M.|author2=Nelson-Porter, B.|author3=Omolaja, M.|name-list-style=amp|year=2012|title=The new alternative women's entrepreneurship education: E-learning and virtual universities|journal=International Women Online Journal of Distance Education|volume=1|issue=2|pages=46–54|url=http://wojde.org/FileUpload/bs295854/File/06a.markovic.pdf|issn=2147-0367|access-date=2015-09-17|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305002329/http://wojde.org/FileUpload/bs295854/File/06a.markovic.pdf|archive-date=2016-03-05|url-status=live}}</ref> They learn skills that help them advance in their careers.
Examples of online activism having an impact include a 2013 online campaign which led to Facebook taking down various pages that spread hatred about women. The campaign was started by 100 female advocates.<ref>{{cite web|author=McVeigh, T.|date=June 6, 2013|title=Online Feminist activists of the digital age|work=Taipei Times|url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/editorials/archives/2013/06/06/2003564076|access-date=September 17, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924123622/http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/editorials/archives/2013/06/06/2003564076|archive-date=September 24, 2015|url-status=live}}</ref> In 2017, when the #AintNoCinderella hashtag emerged, it [[Viral phenomenon|went viral]] after Varnika Kundu (a 29-year-old woman in India) was driving home past midnight on August 4 when she was followed and harassed by two men in a SUV.<ref>{{Cite news |title=#AintNoCinderella: Why Indian women are posting midnight photos |last=Pandey |first=Geeta |work=BBC News |date=2017-08-09 |access-date=2019-02-15 |language=en-GB |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/40872788 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190116211606/https://www.bbc.com/news/40872788 |archive-date=2019-01-16 |url-status=live}}</ref> Kundu was blamed for being out late at night, especially by the BJP government Vice-President Ramveer Bhatti. This led to women across India and other parts of the world to share pictures of themselves out late at night with the hashtag "#AintNoCinderella" to show that women do not have a particular curfew they must follow.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thenewsminute.com/article/ain-t-no-cinderella-women-hit-out-bjp-leader-blaming-chandigarh-stalking-victim-66456|title=Ain't no Cinderella: Women hit out at BJP leader for blaming Chandigarh stalking victim|date=2017-08-08|work=The News Minute|access-date=2018-10-01|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190331073123/https://www.thenewsminute.com/article/ain-t-no-cinderella-women-hit-out-bjp-leader-blaming-chandigarh-stalking-victim-66456|archive-date=2019-03-31|url-status=live}}</ref>
== Ongoing projects == The UN came out with a set of goals called the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) to help make the world a better place.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.un.org/sustainabledevelopment/sustainable-development-goals/|title=Sustainable development goals - United Nations|work=United Nations Sustainable Development|access-date=2018-03-14|language=en-US|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180313165859/http://www.un.org/sustainabledevelopment/sustainable-development-goals/|archive-date=2018-03-13|url-status=live}}</ref> Of the 17th, the fourth goal works to allow access to education for all people. A large effort has been made to include women in schools to better their education.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.un.org/sustainabledevelopment/education/|title=Education - United Nations Sustainable Development|work=United Nations Sustainable Development|access-date=2018-03-14|language=en-US|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180314214606/http://www.un.org/sustainabledevelopment/education/|archive-date=2018-03-14|url-status=live}}</ref> The fifth goal focuses on empowering women and girls to achieve gender equality through equal access to various types of opportunities (health care, education, work, etc.).<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.un.org/sustainabledevelopment/gender-equality/|title=United Nations: Gender equality and women's empowerment|work=United Nations Sustainable Development|access-date=2018-03-14|language=en-US|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180314214620/http://www.un.org/sustainabledevelopment/gender-equality/|archive-date=2018-03-14|url-status=live}}</ref>
=== U.S. involvement === [[File:First Lady Melania Trump and Under Secretary Shannon Pose for a Photo With the 2017 International Women of Courage Awardees (33338548780).jpg|thumb|[[Melania Trump]] with 2017 [[International Women of Courage Award]]ees]] Domestically, the U.S. empowered women through passings of laws such as allowing women to vote in 1920, banning discrimination based on gender in 1964, banning discrimination against pregnant women in 1978, etc. The inclusion of women in politics allowed for more gender equality. The first female speaker of House, the First Lady to run for president, and first women to serve on the Supreme Court were monumental events that provided insight into the developing social acceptance of women in power.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.nwhp.org/resources/womens-rights-movement/detailed-timeline/|title=Detailed Timeline {{!}} National Women's History Project|website=www.nwhp.org|language=en-US|access-date=2018-04-28|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180428051752/http://www.nwhp.org/resources/womens-rights-movement/detailed-timeline/|archive-date=2018-04-28|url-status=live}}</ref>
The U.S. provides foreign aid to third world countries in various forms, one of which is by providing education programs. There are bills in Congress that work to ensure education to girls. One is the Protecting Girls' Access to Education Act. These bills are enacted with the belief that proper education will pull girls out of poverty and reduce exploitation of them.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.congress.gov/bill/115th-congress/house-bill/2408|title=H.R.2408 - 115th Congress (2017-2018): Protecting Girls' Access to Education Act|last=Steve|first=Chabot|date=2017-10-04|website=www.congress.gov|language=en|access-date=2018-03-14|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180413082955/https://www.congress.gov/bill/115th-congress/house-bill/2408|archive-date=2018-04-13|url-status=live}}</ref>
Another action taken on by the U.S is the [[President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief|PEPFAR]] program, initiated by the Bush administration in 2003. The U.S. spent more than $1.4 billion in funding sub-Saharan Africa during the duration of the program. This program was taken into effect in response to the global [[HIV/AIDS]] crisis, and it promoted abstinence among young girls and women.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Cohen|first=Jon|date=June 15, 2007|title=Bush Boosts AIDS Relief: Cause for Applause and Pause|jstor=20036459|journal=Science|volume=316|issue=5831|pages=1552|pmid=17569832|doi=10.1126/science.316.5831.1552|s2cid=43219278}}</ref> There was a partnership with DREAMS, and its main purpose with PEPFAR was to allow both girls and women to develop into Determined, Resilient, Empowered, AIDS-free, Mentored, and Safe women.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.pepfar.gov/partnerships/ppp/dreams/|title=Working Together for an AIDS-Free Future for Girls and Women|website=www.pepfar.gov|language=en-US|access-date=2018-05-04|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180505070203/https://www.pepfar.gov/partnerships/ppp/dreams/|archive-date=2018-05-05|url-status=live}}</ref> There are criticisms that this program did not do much to reduce HIV-risk behavior, and critics such as John Dietrich expressed concern that the context of aid enforced Western beliefs of choosing abstinence before marriage.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Bendavid|first=Eran|display-authors=etal|date=May 2016|title=Abstinence Funding Was Not Associated With Reductions In HIV Risk Behavior In Sub-Saharan Africa|journal=Health Affairs|volume=35|issue=5|pages=856–63|doi=10.1377/hlthaff.2015.0828|pmid=27140992|doi-access=free}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2016/05/03/476601108/u-s-spent-1-4-billion-to-stop-hiv-by-promoting-abstinence-did-it-work|title=U.S. Spent $1.4 Billion To Stop HIV By Promoting Abstinence. Did It Work?|work=NPR.org|access-date=2018-05-04|language=en|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180502222534/https://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2016/05/03/476601108/u-s-spent-1-4-billion-to-stop-hiv-by-promoting-abstinence-did-it-work|archive-date=2018-05-02|url-status=live}}</ref>
